questions.question_text: An administrator needs to back up all the data from each VM daily while also saving space. Which of the following backup types will BEST fit this scenario?

discussion.content: An administrator needs to back up all the data from each VM daily.... ALL THE DATA and DAILY. Its not whats changed since last backup. So I cant see how Incremental or Differencial are correct. Its Synthetic as it also says to reduce the Size of the Backup.

Selected Answer: B
Incremental backups only backup the data that has changed since the last backup, whether it's a full backup or a previous incremental backup. This means that, on a daily basis, you are only backing up the data that is new or has been modified since the last backup. This approach is efficient in terms of storage space because it doesn't duplicate unchanged data.

Differential backups would back up all the data that has changed since the last full backup. While they are more efficient in terms of storage space than full backups, they are less space-efficient than incrementals for daily backups because they include all changes since the last full backup, not just the changes since the last backup of any type.

Selected Answer: B
Incremental backups only back up the data that has changed since the last backup, which in this case is the previous day's backup. It saves space by not duplicating unchanged data and only capturing the changes made to the VMs since the last backup. This approach ensures efficient use of storage resources.

Each day, the incremental backup will only capture and store the data that has been modified or added since the last backup. As a result, the size of each incremental backup is typically smaller than a full or differential backup, making it more space-efficient

questions.question_text: A systems administrator is setting up a backup solution to follow the 3-2-1 policy. Currently, the solution is set to back up from the servers to an on-site storage server. Which of the following should the administrator configure to comply with the 3-2-1 policy?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Has to be D. Only an Offsite server would help them to meet the following 3-2-1 rules

- 3 Copies of Data – Maintain three copies of data—the original, and at least two copies.
- 2 Different Media – Use two different media types for storage. This can help reduce any impact that may be attributable to one specific storage media type. It’s your decision as to which storage medium will contain the original data and which will contain any of the additional copies.
- 1 Copy Offsite – Keep one copy offsite to prevent the possibility of data loss due to a site-specific failure.

Selected Answer: D
D is the right answer.
The 3-2-1 backup policy is a widely recommended strategy for data protection that helps ensure your data is safe from loss. Here’s what it involves:
3-2-1 Backup Policy Breakdown
1. 3 Copies of Your Data**: Maintain three total copies of your data. This includes the original data and two backups. Having multiple copies reduces the risk of losing everything if one fails.
2. 2 Different Storage Media**: Store the backups on at least two different types of storage media. This could include combinations like hard drives, solid-state drives, cloud storage, USB drives, or tape backups. Using different media types protects against media-specific failures.
3. 1 Offsite Location**: Keep at least one backup offsite. This means storing a copy of your data in a different physical location. Offsite storage protects against disasters like fire, flooding, or theft that could affect your primary site.

Selected Answer: D
An off-site storage server ensures that there is a separate physical location where backups are stored, reducing the risk of data loss due to on-site disasters such as fires, floods, or theft.

By configuring an off-site storage server for backups, the administrator ensures compliance with the 3-2-1 backup policy, providing a robust backup strategy that guards against various failure scenarios.

The 3-2-1 backup policy is a widely recommended strategy for ensuring data resilience and recoverability. It involves:

Three copies of data: This means having three separate copies of your data to guard against data loss.
Two different media types: Storing the copies on two different types of storage media helps mitigate risks associated with a single type of failure.
One copy off-site: Keeping at least one copy of the data off-site protects against site-wide disasters.

Selected Answer: D
To comply with the 3-2-1 backup policy, the administrator should configure an off-site storage server for backups. The 3-2-1 backup policy requires three copies of the data, stored in two different formats, with one copy stored off-site. The current backup solution has only one copy of the data (on-site) and should be expanded to include an off-site copy. Weekly full backups and daily incremental backups, storage snapshots, and a second on-site storage server for backups do not necessarily satisfy the 3-2-1 backup policy, although they may be components of a backup solution.

The given answer makes no sense, the Blue-Green setup is designed for the option to fail back, answer should be B for fastest restore of services.

Selected Answer: B
In a blue-green deployment model, the green stack represents the new release, and the blue stack represents the previous release (the stable version). When users report application issues immediately after deploying the green stack, it's a sign that the new release may have problems or is not fully compatible with the production environment.

The fastest way to restore the service and minimize user impact is to failback to the blue stack, which is the stable and previously working version of the application. This allows you to quickly revert to a known good state while you investigate and address the issues with the green stack separately.

Rebooting servers, restoring from backups, or troubleshooting and resolving issues in the green stack may take longer and could potentially worsen the situation if the root cause of the issues is not immediately clear. Failing back to the blue stack provides a rapid and reliable rollback mechanism.

questions.question_text: A systems administrator deployed a new application release to the green stack of a blue-green infrastructure model and made the green stack primary. Immediately afterward, users began reporting application issues. The systems administrator must take action to bring the service online as quickly as possible. Which of the following is the FASTEST way to restore the service?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Replication involves continuously copying data changes from the primary datacenter to the DR site in near real-time. Since the DR site has been operational for a week, setting up replication would allow the primary datacenter's block storage to quickly catch up with the changes made at the DR site. This approach ensures that the primary datacenter becomes up-to-date with minimal data loss and downtime.

Option B (Copy the data across both sites) would likely be inefficient and time-consuming, especially if the amount of data is large, as it involves manually copying data across both sites, which may not capture changes made during the past week.

Option C (Restore incremental backups) and option D (Restore full backups) are not as efficient in this scenario because they involve restoring data from backups, which may not capture all changes made at the DR site since the failure occurred. Additionally, restoring backups could result in longer downtime and potential data loss compared to replication, which provides near real-time data synchronization.

Selected Answer: A
C and D are close, but replication is more closely related to "multi-site" for "coldsite/hotsite" operations. D would take too long, and for C, incrementals just speed up the time for backing up, but you still need to restore the full backup before restoring all the incrementals, so C would also take too long for this case.
